_exec_summary.SummaryText:
6th STREET COOLING, LLC
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN LEVEL III 

1	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.1   Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies.
1.2   General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances.
1.3   Summary of the General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-                Specific Prevention Steps
1.4   Summary of the Five-Year Accident History.
1.5   Summary of the Emergency Response Program.
1.6   Planned Changes To Improve Safety.
This is a 5 year update of the Risk Management Plan for 6th Street Cooling, LLC.  The facility is subject to the Federal Risk Management Program, Cal/OSHA Process Safety Management Program (PSM) and the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (Cal/ARP) in the Level III designation.  The Cal/ARP Program established additional state-specific requirements.  Additional state-specific requirements are addressed in an addendum report submitted to the local implementing agency (Department of Toxic Substance Control/Imperial County Certified Unified Program Agency a.k.a. Imperial CUPA).  

The Southern California Cal/OSHA PSM Unit inspected the facility in late 2008.  Cal/OSHA has cleared the facility of any Prevention Program deficiencies.

1.1  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The 6th Street Cooling Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies are simply not to have accidental releases or emergencies.  The Company endeavors to execute this policy through the daily implementation of its Safety Programs.  The Company safety program includes, but is not limited to a comprehensive Process Safety Management Program (PSM). The PSM Program is an integrated approach to the safe operation of processes using Regulated Substances, and forms the Program Level III Prevention Program component of the RMP.  The PSM Program is specifically designed and intended to prevent accidental releases, and to deal safely with emergencies if and when they do happen.  I

t is the primary goal of 6th Street Cooling to protect its employees, visitors and neighbors from harm due to Company operations. With this in mind, the priorities of protection of life, the environment, and then property have been established.  Only when these goals are achieved may the focus shift to resumption of business operations.

6th Street Cooling has adopted a ¿non-responding facility¿ policy.  A California Hazardous Material Business Plan has been developed and submitted to the local Certified Unified Program Agency; with a copy provided to the Holtville Fire Department.  The Plan is consistent with Emergency Action Plan requirements and includes written regulatory release or threatened release notification requirements.  The Business Plan includes the Hazardous Material Inventory consistent with EPCRA compliance in California, and the information necessary to be included in the Area Emergency Plan.  An Emergency Coordinator has been established.   Emergency response pre-planning is coordinated and kept current through the annual submission of appropriate reports.  The Fire Department has been contacted to make periodic tours of the facility.  Local response capabilities have been verified.  

6th Street Cooling policy includes maintaining appropriate technical capabilities and to deal with incidental releases (as defined by OSHA) safely if and when they do happen.  Key employees have been qualified to use Negative Pressure Respirators; and attend 1910.120(q) Emergency training refreshed annually.  The policy is to support the Local Fire Department with appropriate technical resources in the event of an emergency.


1.2  General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

6th Street Cooling, LLC is a California Limited Liability (LLC) Company made up of Western Precooling Systems ¿ 50% and Saikhon Family LLC ¿ 50%.  The 6th Street Cooling, LLC is responsible for operations at the site.

6th Street Cooling is a seasonally operated fresh

produce refrigeration plant located in Holtville, CA.  Harvest & cooling periods normally begin in early November and conclude in late June each year.  The facility provides refrigeration effect for the removal of field heat from freshly harvested produce and subsequent short-term refrigerated storage until the produce is shipped.  The Plant¿s stationary refrigeration system is supported with portable refrigeration equipment during peak periods.  General maintenance is year-round, with major maintenance occurring in the off-season summer months.

The Regulated Substance in use is anhydrous ammonia (NH3).  Refrigeration equipment consists of Pressure Vessels, HydroVac¿ Vacuum Tubes, Refrigeration Trailers (Compressor Units), Ice-making equipment, Pressure Cooling Equipment, Cold Storage Room Evaporators and associated valves, instrumentation and piping.  

Vacuum tubes and Pressure Coolers are used to pre-cool agricultural product; the refrigerated storage portion of the facility is used for short-term product storage.  Evaporators (Room Units) in the storage sections of the facility maintain temperature until product is sold and shipped.  The refrigeration system is configured in a closed-loop system with isolation and overpressure relief valves installed in key areas. An ammonia-water diffusion system protects against accidental releases from High-Side Pressure Relief Valves.  Refrigerated storage space is monitored with ammonia sensors and an automated alarm system.  

6th Street Cooling, LLC is supported by an affiliate company, Western Precooling Systems (WPS).  WPS is a statewide and well-known provider of ammonia refrigeration equipment and maintenance services.  WPS supports 6th Street Cooling, LLC from its Yuma Operations Office.  Key WPS employees are 1910.120(q) trained and are an additional resource in the event of an emergency. 
   
1.3  General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

Accidental Release Prevention Pr

nt vehicular collisions
¿	Seismic retrofits and bracing are installed 
¿	Process equipment is protected with barriers 
¿	Off-season ammonia storage is protected with an evaporative cooling system (reduce pressure in seasonal hot spells)

1.4  Five-Year Accident History

There is no data to report.  

1.5  The Emergency Response Program

The Emergency Response Program is divided into two elements, as only properly trained and qualified personnel are authorized to respond to emergencies.  Personnel that are not trained to OSHA 1910.120 (q) standards notify and evacuate.  Only the responding Fire Department(s) and 6th Street Cooling¿s 1910.120 (q) trained personnel would respond to an actual emergency.  PPE for 6th Street personnel is maintained on-site.  

The facility maintains required written emergency planning documents.  Written emergency action procedures are detailed in the 6th Street Cooling Hazardous Material Business Plan.  The Hazardous Material Business Plan contains procedures for small spills and procedures for materials other than ammonia.  The Plan is maintained on-site and updated on a regular basis.
  
1.6   Planned changes to improve safety

The primary mechanisms to identify and plan safety improvements include (but are not limited to):
¿	Process Hazard Analysis revalidation/update;
¿	Compliance Audits;
¿	Mechanical Integrity Program maintenance and inspections;
¿	IIAR Bulletin 109 Inspections; and
¿	6th Street Cooling, LLC & WPS Equipment Inspection Protocols

Each of the Programs above may result in recommendations ranging from capital improvements to routine maintenance of the plant.  Work Orders/Service Calls are established in parallel to identified needs.  Current planned changes to improve safety are a result of the latest Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  The improvements were complete as of 12/31/08:

¿	Update the facility site map to indicate Fire Department Access points; and provide a copy of the map to the local Fire Department;
¿	Discon

ogram

A comprehensive Process Safety Management Program (PSM) has been established in accordance with CCR 8, 5189.  The PSM Program is specifically intended to promote the safe operation of ammonia-handling equipment and process, and to prevent accidental releases.  6th Street Cooling, LLC strives to make the PSM Program an integral part of daily Plant operation.  Other safety programs are integrated with the PSM Program, to the extent practicable and appropriate.  The written PSM document is maintained in the site RMP binder/or electronically via wbbm.

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

It has become apparent in the industry that a mishap while draining oil from the system is one of the most common incidents to occur.  Special self-closing valves are installed as a permissive for oil drain flow.  If a release were to develop during the oil-draining task, the mechanic simply releases the handle of the self-closing valve and flow is terminated.  The facility has installed these types of valves at all oil drain points.

¿	Entrance to the facility is closely monitored  
¿	The facility is enclosed with fencing and gates
¿	Employees are trained for hazard communication (discovery and communicating) for releases, fires, vandals, etc.  Training is documented in each employees training record file. 
¿	6th Street Cooling, LLC proactively trains its personnel in the benefits of good housekeeping.  There is a staff to maintain the general appearance of the facility on a day-to-day basis.
¿	Only qualified personnel operate or perform work on the process
¿	The facility is manned while in operation  
¿	Self-closing valves have been installed for process oil draining
¿	Appropriate automatic safety cut-outs are installed on process equipment
¿	Safety cut-outs are regularly inspected and tested
¿	A Diffusion system prevents accidental ¿High Side¿ Pressure Relief Valve lifts from releasing directly to the atmosphere  
¿	Traffic Patterns have been evaluated and established to preve
